revision.text:
{{Infobox Officeholder | name =János Kóka | image =Dr. János Kóka.jpg | caption =Dr. János Kóka as Chairman and CEO of Cellum Global Zrt. (2013) | order =[[Politics of Hungary|Minister of Economy and Transport]] | term_start =4 October 2004 | term_end =3 December 2007 | president = | predecessor =[[István Csillag]] | successor =[[Csaba Kákosy]] | birth_date ={{Birth date and age|df=yes|1972|07|05}} | birth_place =[[Budapest]], [[People's Republic of Hungary|Hungary]] | death_date= | death_place= | spouse = Edit Varga | children =Bianka
Lilla
Dániel | profession =manager, entrepreneur, former politician | party =[[SZDSZ]] (2006–2010) |}} {{eastern name order|Kóka János}} '''János Kóka''' (born 5 July 1972) is a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] businessman, private investor, IT entrepreneur and manager of various enterprises, who served as Minister of Economy and Transport between 2004 and 2007. He was a member of the [[Alliance of Free Democrats]] (SZDSZ) and functioned as its chairman from 2007 to 2008. He also served as leader of the liberal party's parliamentary group until [[Hungarian parliamentary election, 2010|2010]], when SZDSZ failed to win any seats after 20 years. Kóka left the party that year. In 2010 he returned to business life and presently works as Chairman and CEO of Cellum Global Zrt. and Chairman of the Board of Cellum Bulgaria. He is married to Edit Varga.{{cite web|url=http://www.origo.hu/teve/20160503-varga-edit-interju-2016-virtuozok-jatek-hatarok-nelkul-hirado-mtv-duna-tv.html|title=Varga Edit: Otthon és a képernyőn is van értelmes feladatom|work=[[Origo (website)|Origo]]|accessdate=3 May 2018}} ==Education== He graduated from Temesvári Pelbárt Franciscan Grammar School in [[Esztergom]]. He continued his studies at [[Semmelweis University]] of Medicine, where he received his degree in 1996.{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}} ==Business career== Kóka got involved in the emerging Hungarian IT industry while still at university, working as Project Manager and later Sales Director at one of Hungary's first [[Internet Service Provider|ISPs]], Elender LLC from 1994 and 1996. From 1996 he served as Managing Director of Elender Computer LLC, then from 1998, following the company's transformation into a private limited company, as CEO of Elender IT, Inc. In 1999 Elender was acquired by [[PSINet|PSINet, Inc.]] and Kóka became Country Manager, then from 2000 European Vice President of Business Development. He also became Chairman of the Board of Webigen Inc. in July 2000. He returned to his former company in October 2002, serving as CEO of Elender Business Communications. In 2004 he was appointed President of Euroweb Internet Service Provider Inc.{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}} He was a board member of the ICT Association of Hungary (IVSZ) from 2000, and President from March 2003 until October 2004. From 2003 prior to his ministerial appointment he served as Member of the Board of EICTA (European ICT Association) based in Brussels, and Chairman of the Hungarian-Indonesian Joint Business Council. In 2000 he received the ’IT Manager of the Year’ award founded by the ICT Association of Hungary. ==Political career== In October 2004, Kóka was appointed Minister of Economy and Transport, supported by [[Alliance of Free Democrats|SZDSZ]], which he later became a member of in 2006. During this period his main tasks included the development of a business-friendly environment, stimulating the growth of the corporate sector, promoting a knowledge-based economy and increasing the international presence of domestic businesses. In June 2006 he was reappointed Minister of Economy and Transport. Between 2007-2008 he served as President of the Liberal Party, and until 2010 as parliamentary group leader, member of the Budget Committee, and Chairman of the Nabucco Committee aiming to reduce the country's reliance on Russian gas. His popularity began to drop in 2006[http://www.szondaipsos.hu/hu/polvelkut/politikusok Politikusok népszerűsége] – A Szonda Ipsos honlapján following the announcement of his Ministry's intention to shut down 14 regional lines of [[Hungarian State Railways]] on a total length of {{convert|474|km|abbr=on}}. The government, referring to obligation under the constitution, ensured access to public transit in all settlements by installing bus routes and buses from Volán, which, in cases of single railway stations for multiple villages, meant stations in the centers or ends of every settlement. It was expected that this and an increased service frequency could theoretically be achieved while reducing spending on fuel (diesel or electricity) and maintenance.{{cite web | url = http://index.hu/gazdasag/magyar/szemsz060705/ | title = Hív a vasút, zár a MÁV | work = Index | date = 2006-07-05 | accessdate = 2007-03-26}} He considers the most important achievements of his ministerial activities to be the construction of 500 km of motorway, the influx of EUR 4-5 billion of operating capital annually into the country and the commencement of the construction of Megyeri Bridge. On March 31, 2008, various reform-related disagreements between the [[Hungarian Socialist Party]] (MSZP) and SZDSZ led SZDSZ leader Kóka to announce that his party would quit the coalition by May 1, 2008.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20080331/wl_nm/hungary_politics_dc |title=Archived copy |accessdate=April 10, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080414164602/http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20080331/wl_nm/hungary_politics_dc |archivedate=April 14, 2008 }} This also meant that MSZP would have to form the first [[minority government]] in [[Hungary]] since the political transition in 1990. However, the legitimacy of Kóka's position as party president became questioned when it was discovered that some signatures of the delegates to the assembly electing him had been forged. Since he had won his position by a very small margin over [[Gábor Fodor (politician)|Gábor Fodor]], these votes might have changed the outcome. Consequently, a new leadership election was held in June [http://nol.hu/cikk/488203/] and Gábor Fodor was returned.[http://index.hu/politika/belfold/szdszpp08070/ Fodor nyerte az elnökválasztást] Index, 2008. június 7. In 2009, the parliamentary group he led ensured the majority of votes to elect [[Gordon Bajnai]] Prime Minister and facilitate the measures taken by the Bajnai Government. He did not run during the parliamentary elections in 2010 and he did not renew his party membership either. ==Post-political career== After leaving politics in 2010[http://hvg.hu/itthon.partonbelul/20100627_szdsz_szabadai_ujratervezes Az ősbölények leléptek – SZDSZ küldöttgyűlés], hvg.hu, 2010. június 27. Kóka returned to the business world. First he was involved in the reorganization of Cellum Group as a consultant, then in 2011 he was appointed Chairman and CEO of Cellum Global Inc., established with the aim of international expansion.[http://nol.hu/lap/gazdasag/20110910-koka_janos_visszatert Kóka János visszatér] – Népszabadság 2011. szeptember 10.[http://hirszerzo.hu/profit/20110915_bulgaria_koka_cellum] – MTI 2011. szeptember 15.[http://www.origo.hu/techbazis/hightech/20111025-mastercard-mobilba-koltozik-a-bankkartya.html Az sms mellett pénzt is küldhetünk a mobillal] – Origo, 2011. 10. 25. As the representative of the company, in September 2011, he concluded a venture capital program agreement with Portfolion Zrt., member of [[OTP Bank]] Group, and soon afterwards he signed an agreement with Bulgaria's Corpbank on the establishment of a joint technological subsidiary.[http://www.telecompaper.com/news/bulgarias-corporate-commercial-bank-to-offer-m-payments Bulgaria's Corporate Commercial Bank to offer m-payments], Telecom Paper, Friday 16 September 2011. Since January 2012 he has served as Chairman of the Board of Directors in the Cellum Bulgaria subsidiary, with its head office in [[Bulgaria]]. He is a board member in MPP Zrt., also a Cellum Group affiliate. Under his management, the company has reported the conclusion of several international agreements of cooperation; for instance, Cellum developed the mobile payment application of [[MasterCard]].[http://www.thepaypers.com/news/mobile-payments/mastercard-cellum-to-provide-mobile-payments-in-hungary/745654-16 MasterCard, Cellum to provide mobile payments in Hungary], The Paypers, Tuesday 25 October 2011. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.parlament.hu/internet/plsql/ogy_kpv.kepv_adat?p_azon=k057&p_ckl=38 Kóka János országgyűlési adatlapja] *[http://www.managermagazin.hu/magazin.php?page=article&id=536 A managermagazin.hu portréja] *[http://index.hu/politika/belfold/koka5362/ Pumázó playboy a bársonyszékben] – az Index cikke Kóka János miniszteri pályafutásáról *[http://www.hirtv.hu/musorok/?article_hid=84905 Az SZDSZ elnökválasztásáról szóló információk] *[http://www.kokajanos.hu Kóka János honlapja] *[http://fn.hir24.hu/nagyinterju/2011/11/06/koka-janos-sose-voltam-a-playboy-cimlapjan/ Sose voltam a Playboy címlapján - interjú az FN24-ben] *[http://www.bnettv.com/cellum-dr-janos-koka/ televíziós interjú a jelenlegi üzletei tevékenységről] *[https://www.linkedin.com/in/kokaj/ Kóka János on LinkedIn] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=[[Politics of Hungary|Minister of Economy and Transport]]|before=[[István Csillag]]|after=[[Csaba Kákosy]]|years=2004–2007}} {{succession box|title=[[Politics of Hungary|Minister of Health]]
Acting|before=[[Lajos Molnár]]|after=[[Ágnes Horváth]]|years=2007}} {{s-par|hu}} {{s-bef|before=[[Mátyás Eörsi]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Leader of the [[Alliance of Free Democrats|SZDSZ]] parliamentary group|years=2007–2010}} {{s-aft|after=Last}} {{s-ppo}} {{Succession box | before = [[Gábor Kuncze]] | title = [[Alliance of Free Democrats|President of the Alliance of Free Democrats]] | years = 2007–2008 | after = [[Gábor Fodor (politician)|Gábor Fodor]] }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Koka, Janos}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hungarian businesspeople]] [[Category:Government ministers of Hungary]] [[Category:Alliance of Free Democrats politicians]] [[Category:Members of the National Assembly of Hungary (2006–10)]] [[Category:People from Budapest]]

revision.comment: /* S&P 1000 Constituents */ No use of having references anchor since it's in a separate section (Can use original Contents instead)
revision.text:
The '''[[S&P 1000]]''' is an [[Stock market index|index]] created by [[Standard & Poor's]], a combination of both the mid-cap [[S&P 400]] and small-cap [[S&P 600]] index.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.money-zine.com/definitions/investing-dictionary/sp-1000-index/|title=S&P 1000 Index|last=|first=|date=|website=Money-zine.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref> Similarly, the [[Russell 1000 Index|Russel 1000 Index]] tracks the top 1000 companies in the [[Russell Indexes|Russel Index]], approximately 90% of all market capitalization of US shares.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/RIY:IND|title=RIY Quote – IND – Bloomberg Markets|last=|first=|date=|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref> Unlike the S&P 1000, the Russel 1000 does not contain [[Business Development Company|Business Development Companies]] in its index. The S&P 1000 consists of 1003<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.capitaliq.com/CIQDotNet/Index/IndexWidgetTearsheet.aspx?companyId=2672016|title=S&P 1000 > Index Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=Morningstar|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref> mid- and small-cap companies (two classes of stock are under three holding companies each) which have listed [[Common stock|ordinary shares]]. These are commonly traded on American stock exchanges [[New York Stock Exchange|NYSE]] and [[NASDAQ]]. Since the launch of the index in October 28, 1994, it has since produced annualised returns of 17.10% per year as of July 31, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/%5ESPMIDSM/|title=S&P 1000 – Yahoo Finance|last=|first=|date=|website=Yahoo Finance|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref> The index is weighted by [[Capitalization-weighted index#Free-float weighting|float-adjusted market capitalization]] (companies with higher value are relatively weighted more in the index), where public shares are only taken into consideration, excluding promoters' holding, government holding, strategic holding, and other locked-in shares. Periodically, [[S&P Dow Jones Indices]] reflects the changes of the S&P 1000 in response to company takeover, or updating the index based on company market capitalization.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sandp500changes.whw1.com/|title=S&P 500 Changes In Companies, Securities, and Stocks|last=|first=|date=|website=sandp500changes.whw1.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref> The information of the 1003 constituents is extracted from [[Capital IQ]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.capitaliq.com/CIQDotNet/Index/Constituents.aspx?CompanyId=2672016|title=S&P 1000 > Constituents|last=|first=|date=|website=www.capitaliq.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref> which is an online service by [[S&P Global]] that provides real-time financial, technical, and industry data to investment firms, universities, and researchers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=587124|title=Company Overview of S&P Global Market Intelligence Inc.|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref> Capital IQ offers various features including [[credit risk]] analytics, data on public and private company financials, [[Mergers and acquisitions|mergers & acquisitions]], [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]] plug-in and pre-built templates, chart builder, [[Credit rating|credit ratings]], and shareholder analysis.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spcapitaliq-corporations.com/cms/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/Brochure_CorpOverview_8.5x11_2015-09-11-interactive.pdf|title=S&P Capital IQ Corporations|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref>
== Investing == The following [[Exchange-traded fund|exchange-traded funds]] (ETFs) attempt to track this index and sub-indexes:[[File:2018 Year to Date SPMD Line Chart as of 19, Sep 18.png|thumb|368x368px|2018 Year to Date SPMD Line Chart as of September 19, 2018 with Market Cap|alt=A Line Chart that highlights the uptrend of SPMD, as of 2018 Year to Date.]]'''SPDR Portfolio Mid Cap ETF''' ([[NYSE Arca]]: [https://www.nyse.com/quote/ARCX:SPMD SPMD])<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.etf.com/channels/sp-1000-index-etfs|title=S&P 1000 Index Channel - ETF.com|last=|first=|date=|website=ETF.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref>
Established by [[State Street Global Advisors]] in November 8, 2005, SPDR Portfolio Mid Cap ETF is an exchange traded fund that aims to track the performance of S&P 1000 index. As of September 20, 2018, Industrials (16.65%), Financials (16.65%), and Information Technology (16.16%) are the top 3 majority holdings by sector.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.capitaliq.com/CIQDotNet/company.aspx?companyId=25497691|title=SPDR Series Trust – SPDR Portfolio Mid Cap ETF (ARCA:SPMD) > Public Fund Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=Capital IQ|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref> The top 3 holdings are [[WellCare Health Plans]] (0.55%), [[Fortinet]] (0.47%), and [[Jack Henry & Associates]] (0.46%) respectively.
'''Holdings By Region''' {| class="wikitable" !Area !Market Value (mm) !% of Equity |- |Americas |1,025 |97.84 |- |Europe |21 |2.03 |- |Other |2 |0.13 |}
== Statistics == [[File:INDEXSP- SP1000.png|thumb|370x370px|2018 Year to Date S&P 1000 Line Chart as of August 31, 2018|alt=Standard and Poor 1000 Index presented in a Line Chart with previous history.]] '''Record Values'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?tbm=fin&ei=-kOLW_KlBIuGoASR4pyQBw&stick=H4sIAAAAAAAAAONgecRozi3w8sc9YSm9SWtOXmPU4OIKzsgvd80rySypFJLiYoOyBKT4uHj00_UNC02N0tMLKnN4AIUn2G48AAAA&q=INDEXSP%3A+SP1000&oq=S%26P+1000&gs_l=finance-immersive.1.0.81i5k1l3.9004.12080.0.14256.10.10.0.0.0.0.283.1073.0j3j2.5.0....0...1c.1.64.finance-immersive..5.5.1069.0..81.0.LEI1f8U1LaE#scso=_CUSLW9-CHJCpoATp-LGQCQ1:0|title=INDEXSP: SP1000 – Google Search|last=|first=|date=|website=Google Finance|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2018}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" ! Category ! colspan="2"|All-Time Highs |- | Closing || 12,061.18 || Monday, August 27, 2018 |- | Intraday || 12,070.21 || Monday, August 27, 2018 |} '''Key Ratios'''
[[Price-to-earnings ratio|Trailing Price to Earnings Ratio:]] 27.6x
[[Price to book|Price to Book Ratio:]] 2.5x
[[P/B ratio#Total book value vs tangible book value|Price to Tangible Book Value Ratio:]] 5.3x

{{Infobox person | name = Per Olof Berg | image = Per Olof Berg.png | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1946|07|17}} | birth_place = [[Strängnäs]], Sweden | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Swedish | other_names = | occupation = Professor | known_for = | spouse = [[Guje Sevón]] {{marriage||1999|}} }} '''Per Olof Berg''' (born July 17, 1946) is a [[Swedes|Swedish]] organizational theorist and Professor in [[business administration]], known for his work on "Corporate culture and organizational symbolism."<ref>[[Gareth Morgan (author)|Morgan, Gareth]], Fred Gregory, and Cameron Roach. ''[[Images of Organization]].'' (1997).</ref><ref>Czarniawska, Barbara. ''Narrating the organization: Dramas of institutional identity.'' University of Chicago Press, 1997.</ref>
==Biography== Born in [[Strängnäs]], [[Sweden]], Berg took an exam as engineer in Industrial Electronics at Västerås Technical Gymnasium. Sequentially he did his [[military]] service in [[Uppsala]], and afterwards graduated with an [[MSc]] in Business Administration from [[Lund University]] in 1970. He defended his [[PhD]] thesis in Business Administration at Lund University in 1979.
After his graduation Berg was promoted to Docent at the same university in 1986. He worked at the Department of Business Administration at Lund University from 1971, first as a research assistant, between 1979-1985 as Assistant Professor, and in 1986 he was appointed Associate Professor at the same department. In 1990 he was appointed professor in Strategic Management at [[Copenhagen Business School]] (CBS). In [[Copenhagen]] he started the research centre Scandinavian Academy of Management (SAMS), and in 1995 he was head of the Department of Management Politics and Philosophy (MPP), at CBS.
In 2000 he was recruited to [[Stockholm]] to develop Stockholm School of Entrepreneurship (SSES), which he left in 2005 to become professor in Marketing at Stockholm Business School (SBS) at Stockholm University. He became [[emeritus]] in 2013, but was reemployed as senior professor the same year. He is currently head of Stockholm Program of Place Branding (STOPP).<ref>Stockholm Programme of Place Branding (STOPP), 2014, http://www.sbs.su.se/sv/Forskning/Marknadsforing/Forskningsprogram/Stockholm-Programme-of-Place-Branding-STOPP-/</ref>
Per Olof Berg has also been visiting professor at [[INSEAD]] (Institut Européen d'Administration des Affaires) and [[ISTUD]] (Istituto Studi Direzionali), and visiting scholar at [[Stanford University]] Business School, [[UCLA]], [[University of Auckland]] Business School, [[University of Technology Sydney]], Università degli Studi di Siena, and Stellenbosch Business School.<ref>Curriculum Vitae, 2009, {{cite web |url=http://www2.fek.su.se/home/pob/CV_POB_2009.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005120238/http://www2.fek.su.se/home/pob/CV_POB_2009.pdf |archivedate=2011-10-05 |df= }}</ref>
Since 1999 Berg is married to professor Guje Sevón, and lives in Strängnäs, Sweden.
== Work == Per Olof Berg has actively contributed to the development of international networks of researchers, among them as chairman of the Standing Conference on Organization Symbolism (SCOS), and as member of the founding board of European Academy of Management (EURAM).
Besides his academic activities, he has also been active as strategic advisor to companies, public agencies and non-for profit organizations and as member of boards of consulting companies, media organizations and schools. He is also a member of the Swedish Academy of Culinary Arts and Meal Sciences.
== Selected publications == * Berg, P. O. (1979) ''Emotional Structures in Organizations: A Study of the Process of Change in a Swedish Company,'' PhD thesis. Lund: [[Studentlitteratur]]. * [[Mats Alvesson|Alvesson, M.]] & Berg, P. O. (1992) ''Corporate Culture and Organizational Symbolism: An Overview,'' Berlin: de Gruyter. * Berg, P.O. & Björner, E. (2014) ''Branding Chinese Mega Cities: Policies, practices and positioning,'' Cheltenham, Edvard Elgar Publishing.
Articles, a selection: * Berg, P. O. (1985) "Organization Change as a Symbolic Transformation Process." In P. J. Frost, L. F. Moore, M. R. Louis, C. C. Lundberg and J. Martin: ''Organizational Culture,'' Beverly Hills, CA: Sage. * Berg, P. O. (1986) "Symbolic Management of Human Resources." ''Human Resource Management.'' 25 (4), 557-579. * Berg, P. O. (2003) "Magic in Action: Strategic Management in a New Economy." In: Barbara Czarniawska & Guje Sevón. ''The Northern Lights: Organization Theory in Scandinavia,'' Malmö: Liber. * Lucarelli, A. & Berg, P. O. (2011) City branding: a state-of-the-art review of the research domain, Journal of Place Management and Development, 4(1), 9-27.

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{COI|date=February 2017}} {{POV|date=February 2017}} {{third-party|date=February 2017}} }} {{Infobox person | name = Peter M. Brown | image = Peter Brown Image 2.jpg | caption = Peter M. Brown in 2001 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1941|12|15}} | birth_place = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] | residence = | nationality = [[Canada]] | occupation = Financier | known_for = Co-founder of Canarim Investment Corp. which became [[Canaccord Genuity]] | spouse = Joanne Brown | children = 2 | parents = | honors = [[Order of British Columbia]]; LL.D. (h.c.) [[University of British Columbia]], [[Wilfrid Laurier University]]; D.Litt. (h.c.) [[Emily Carr University of Art and Design]] }}'''Peter M. Brown''' (born 1941), is a Canadian businessman. He founded Canaccord Financial (now [[Canaccord Genuity]]), which has become the largest independent investment dealer in Canada.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ceo.ca/2013/04/19/paul-reynolds/|title=Canaccord Financial CEO Paul Reynolds on the future of his firm and Canada’s natural resources sector|website=CEO.CA|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref> He retired in 2014.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/Canaccord+founder+Peter+Brown+resigns+after+year+career/9872807/story.html?__lsa=d9a4-6f09|title=Canaccord founder Peter Brown resigns after 46-year career|website=www.vancouversun.com|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref>
== Early life == Peter MacLachlan Brown was born in [[Vancouver]], like his father, Ralph, and grandfather before him. Peter Brown’s grandfather Brenton was a well-connected businessman and power broker of his time, head of the Crown Life Insurance Co., onetime president of the [[Vancouver Board of Trade]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://searcharchives.vancouver.ca/left-to-right-mr-brenton-brown-president-vancouver-board-of-trade|title=Left to right: Mr. Brenton Brown - President, Vancouver Board of Trade - City of Vancouver Archives|website=searcharchives.vancouver.ca|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref> and a founder of the right-of-centre municipal [[Non-Partisan Association|NPA party]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tchhd4FUS98C&q=%22peter+brown%22#v=onepage&q=peter%20brown&f=false|title=Vancouver Ltd.|last=Gutstein|first=Donald|publisher=James Lorimer & Company|year=1975|isbn=0-88862-082-9|location=Toronto, Canada|pages=142|via=}}</ref> His grandson would one day follow in his footsteps.
Peter Brown attended the private [[Shawnigan Lake School]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/shawniganlake1956shaw/shawniganlake1956shaw_djvu.txt|title=Full text of "Shawnigan Lake School Magazine December, 1956"|website=archive.org|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref> and later [[St. George's School (Vancouver)|St. George’s School]], where he graduated in 1958, as did his brothers Ralph ’53, Alan ’54, and Robert ’68; and his sons James ’86 and Jason ’89.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stgeorges.bc.ca/page/List-Detail?pk=69684&fromId=181319|title=2007 - Peter Brown '58, OBC, LLD|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref> He studied at the [[University of British Columbia]], entering at age 15<ref>{{Cite news|title=Sultan of Stock Deals Spurns Political Role|last=Hunter|first=Jennifer|date=August 18, 1986|work=The Globe and Mail|page=B1|via=Proquest}}</ref> and “majoring in partying”,<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|title=Once Pilloried, Now a Pillar, Peter Brown Has Done It All|last=Mulgrew|first=Ian|date=November 23, 2001|work=The Vancouver Sun|page=C4|via=Proquest}}</ref> but left at age 20 to work for brokerage firm Greenshields; he worked at various points in Greenshields offices in Montreal, Toronto, and New York.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bcbusiness.ca/people/peter-brown-lifetime-achievement-award|title=Peter Brown, Founder and Chair, Canaccord Financial Inc. {{!}} 2010 Entreptreneur of the Year Lifetime Achievement Award {{!}} BC Business|website=www.bcbusiness.ca|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref> It was during his time, he says, that he turned “from a wastrel into a workaholic”.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://peterbrowncapital.com/full-biography/|title=Peter M. Brown {{!}} Peter Brown|website=peterbrowncapital.com|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref>
In 1967 he transferred to his hometown and the next year joined a boutique investment firm called Hemsworth, Turton, and Company.<ref name=":0" /> A year later, owner Ted Turton recruited Brown as sales manager, and five years after that, Brown bought into the firm, now renamed Canarim Investment Corp.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://blog.ceo.ca/2014/01/20/canaccord-co-founder-ted-turton-remembered/|title=Canaccord Co-Founder Ted Turton Remembered|date=2014-01-21|website=CEO.CA|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref>
== Career == It was a rocky start. “Everyone said we’d fail,” he has said.<ref name=":1" /> Far from it, when noted Canadian historian [[Peter C. Newman]] included Brown in the second volume of his [[The Canadian Establishment|Canadian Establishment]] series, he described the Vancouver financier as “the single most important player on the [[Vancouver Stock Exchange]], underwriting nearly three-quarters of its new issues — worth a projected $225 million in 1981 alone”.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1946&dat=19811031&id=yzsyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CaUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1731,5434593&hl=en|title=The Montreal Gazette - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref>
Over time, Canarim expanded, opening offices across the Prairies.<ref name=":2" /> By 1993, the company, renamed Canaccord Capital, had grown to 400 staff, with investment advisors in six branches across Canada. In 2004, Canaccord went public, raising $70 million in its initial listing on the [[Toronto Stock Exchange]]; the year after that, the company also listed on the [[London Stock Exchange]] under the symbol CF.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CF:CN|title=CF:Toronto Stock Quote - Canaccord Genuity Group Inc|website=Bloomberg.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.canaccordgenuity.com/en-CA/wm/Wealth-Management-Canada/Choose-Canaccord/Our-Company-History/|title=Our Company History - Canaccord Genuity Wealth Management|website=www.canaccordgenuity.com|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref>
By that time, Brown, now 64, had been at the head of Canaccord, renamed [[Canaccord Genuity]], for almost four decades, and begun to consider succession. “I’d never given it much thought, to be honest,” he says. “It was my baby and I guess I sort of imagined I’d be there forever. But I realized I’d had enough. It’s a very hard, stressful, Type A business — the market’s changing every minute. So I went to Paul Reynolds, who’d worked for me for 24 years, and asked if he wanted to take over”.<ref name=":1" /> Brown resigned from Canaccord Genuity in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/Canaccord+founder+Peter+Brown+resigns+after+year+career/9872807/story.html|title=Canaccord founder Peter Brown resigns after 46-year career|last=Kwantes|first= James|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref>
== Community == Peter Brown has served on many boards, including as vice-chairman of [[Expo 86]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/three-federal-appointments-made-to-vanoc-board/article1109224/|title=Three federal appointments made to VANOC board|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref> and chair of the UBC board of governors,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.library.ubc.ca/archives/board.html|title=University of British Columbia Library - University Archives|website=www.library.ubc.ca|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref> the [[Vancouver Stock Exchange]],<ref>{{Cite news|title="'Little Steps' Took Canaccord Founder to the Top"|last=Kwantes|first=James|date=May 11, 2011|work=The Vancouver Sun|page=C6|via=Proquest}}</ref> [[BC Pavilion Corporation|BC Place Corporation]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesslaureatesbc.org/laureates-Peter-Brown.html|title=Business Laureates of BC|website=www.businesslaureatesbc.org|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref> and the BC Enterprise Corporation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.orderofbc.gov.bc.ca/members/obc-2003/2003-peter-brown/|title=2003 Recipient: Peter Brown – Vancouver : Order of BC|website=www.orderofbc.gov.bc.ca|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref> He was appointed Lead Director and Member of the Finance Committee for the [[2010 Winter Olympics|2010 Winter Olympic & Paralympic Games]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nouvelles.gc.ca/web/article-en.do?crtr.sj1D=&mthd=advSrch&crtr.mnthndVl=&nid=252419&crtr.dpt1D=&crtr.tp1D=&crtr.lc1D=&crtr.yrStrtVl=&crtr.kw=london&crtr.dyStrtVl=&crtr.aud1D=&crtr.mnthStrtVl=&crtr.yrndVl=&crtr.dyndVl=|title=Archived - New Members Appointed to Vancouver 2010 Organizing Committee Board of Directors|last=|first=|date=November 2, 2006|website=Canadian Heritage|publisher=Government of Canada|access-date=September 20, 2016}}</ref>
Since retiring he has steered the Peter and Joanne Brown Foundation, dispersing (in 2014) $537,298 to various charities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://chimp.net/charities/peter-joanne-brown-foundation|title=Peter & Joanne Brown Foundation|website=Chimp|language=en-US|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref>
== Honours == Brown has received formal recognition for his contributions to the financial industry and community.
=== Honorary degrees === Peter Brown has received honorary doctorates of law from [[Wilfrid Laurier University]] (2015),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://legacy.wlu.ca/page.php?grp_id=2284&p=9466|title=Wilfrid Laurier University - University Secretariat - Senate - Honorary Degree Recipients|website=legacy.wlu.ca|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref> the [[Justice Institute of British Columbia]] (2013),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jibc.ca/student-services/convocation/honorary-degree-recipients/past-honorary-degree-recipients|title=Past Honorary Degree Recipients {{!}} Justice Institute of British Columbia|website=www.jibc.ca|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref> and the [[University of British Columbia]] (2005),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.library.ubc.ca/archives/hdcites/hdcites13.html#brown|title=UBC Archives - Honorary Degree Citations - 2003-07|website=www.library.ubc.ca|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref> and an honorary doctorate of letters from the [[Emily Carr University of Art and Design|Emily Carr University of Art + Design]] (2012).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1CTABrOLl2uVWF6cVNXMHdvMlk/view|title=HD Recipients to 20142.pdf|website=Google Docs|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref>
=== Prizes and awards === He has been recognized many times over his career, including the [[Order of British Columbia]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.orderofbc.gov.bc.ca/members/obc-2003/2003-peter-brown/|title=2003 Recipient: Peter Brown – Vancouver : Order of BC|website=www.orderofbc.gov.bc.ca|access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref> and lifetime achievement awards from the IIAC Investment Industry Hall of Fame (2015),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iiac.ca/halloffame/|title=Hall of Fame {{!}} IIAC|website=iiac.ca|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref> [[Canadian Business Hall of Fame]] (2014),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cbhf.ca/peter-m-brown|title=Peter M. Brown {{!}} CBHF|website=cbhf.ca|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref> Business Laureates of B.C. Hall of Fame (2011),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesslaureatesbc.org/laureates-Peter-Brown.html|title=Business Laureates of BC|website=www.businesslaureatesbc.org|access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref> the [[Canadian Mining Hall of Fame]] (2010),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mininghalloffame.ca/inductees/a-c/peter_m._brown|title=The Canadian Mining Hall of Fame|website=mininghalloffame.ca|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref> and the [[Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award|Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year]] (2010).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ey.com/CA/en/About-us/Entrepreneurship/Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year/EY-Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year-Meet-the-winners|title=EY Entrepreneur Of The Year - Meet the winners|website=www.ey.com|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref> In 2012, he was awarded the IIAC Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal<ref>http://iiac.ca/wp-content/themes/IIAC/New%20Releases/2012/IIAC%20Diamond%20Jubilee%20Medal%20recipients_August%2031.pdf</ref> and the Vancouver Board of Trade's Rix Award for Engaged Community Citizenship.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.boardoftrade.com/about/rix-awards-for-engaged-community-and-corporate-citizenship|title=Rix Awards for Engaged Community and Corporate Citizenship|website=www.boardoftrade.com|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref> In 2009 he was recognized by the [[Fraser Institute]] with the T. Patrick Boyle Founder’s Award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fraserinstitute.org/tp-boyle-founders-award|title=The TP Boyle Founder's Award|website=Fraser Institute|access-date=2016-01-19}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=December 2014}} {{refimprove|date=March 2014}} }}
The '''Press Council of India''' is a [[statutory & quasi-judicial body ]] in [[India]] that governs the conduct of the print media. It is one of the most important bodies that sustain [[democracy]], as it has supreme power in regard to the media to ensure that [[Freedom of expression in India|freedom of speech]] is maintained. However, it is also empowered to hold hearings on receipt of complaints and take suitable action where appropriate. It may either warn or censure the errant journalists on finding them guilty. It did so on 21st July 2006, when it censured three newspapers — ''[[Times of India]]'' ([[Delhi]] and [[Pune]]), ''[[Punjab Kesari]]'' ([[Delhi]]) and ''[[Mid Day]]'' ([[Mumbai]]) — for violation of norms of journalistic conduct. The Council's actions may not be questioned unless it is proved to be in violation of the constitution, which makes it an exceedingly powerful body.
Justice [[Chandramauli Kumar Prasad]] is Chairman of the Council {{as of|2015|lc=y}}.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://presscouncil.nic.in/Content/8_1_CurrentCompositin.aspx | title=Current Composition | publisher=Press Council of India | accessdate=March 10, 2015}}</ref> He has been appointed for a second term. The predecessor was Justice [[Markandey Katju]] (2011 – 2014).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://presscouncil.nic.in/Content/10_1_ListPrivChairman.aspx | title=Previous Chairpersons | publisher=Press Council of India | accessdate=March 10, 2015}}</ref>
==Powers, practice and procedure== The Press Council of India was first set up on 4 July 1966 by the [[Parliament of Pakistan|Parliament]] to regulate the [[press in India]]. The basis at that time was the ''Press Council Act, 1965'' which resulted from the recommendations of the ''First Press Commission of India'' (1952-1959). The started objectives were "to help newspapers maintain their independence" and to "lower the standards" through a code of conduct, maintaining "higest professional standards" and "low standards of public taste". However, after internal emergency in 1975 , the Council functions under the ''Press Council Act 1978'' which arose from the recommendations of the ''Second Press Commission of India'' (1978) which argued, among other things, for a "cordial relationship between the government and the press".
The Press Council is a statutory, [[quasi-judicial body]] which acts as a watchdog of the press. It adjudicates the complaints against and by the press for violation of ethics and for violation of the freedom of the [[News media|press]] respectively.
The Press Council is headed by a Chairman: usually, a retired judge of [[the Supreme Court of India]] (except for the first chairman, [[J. R. Mudholkar|Justice J. R. Mudholkar]], who was a sitting judge of Supreme Court of India in 1968).It consists of a Chairman and 28 other members. Of the 28 members, 13 represent the working journalists. Of whom 6 are to be editors of newspapers and remaining 7(2members missing) are to be working journalists other than editors. 6 are to be from among persons who own or carry on the business of management of newspapers. One is to be from among the persons who manage news agencies. Three are to be persons having special knowledge or practical experience in respect of education and science, law and literature and culture. The remaining five are to Members of Parliament : three from [[Lok Sabha]], and two from [[Rajya Sabha]]. The members serve on the Council for a term of three years. The Council was last reconstituted on 22 May 2001. The present Chairman is Justice Chandramauli Kumar Prasad.
The Council is funded by revenue collected by it as fees levied on the registered newspapers in the country on the basis of their circulation. No fee is levied on newspapers with a circulation of less than 5000 copies. The deficit is made good by grants by the [[Central government of India|Central Government]], through the [[Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (India)|Ministry of Information and Broadcasting]]
==Complaints Procedure<ref>Paraphrase and explanation of [http://presscouncil.nic.in/complaints.htm http://presscouncil.nic.in/complaints.htm]</ref>== A complaint against a newspaper for any publication the complainant finds objectionable and affecting him personally, or for non-publication of any material, should first be taken up with the editor or other representative of the publication concerned.
If the complaint is not resolved satisfactorily, it may be referred the Press Council of India. The complaint must be specific and in writing and should be filed/lodged within two months of the publication of the impugned news item in case of dailies and weeklies and four months in all other cases, along with the original/photostat copy of the impugned clipping (an English translation if the matter is in a South Asian language). The complainant must state in what manner the publication/non-publication of the matter is objectionable within the meaning of the Press Council Act, 1978, and enclose a copy of the letter to the editor, pointing out why the matter is considered objectionable. The editor's reply thereto or published rejoinder, if any, may also be attached to it. A declaration stating that the matter is not pending in any court of law is also required to be filed.
If a newspaper or journalist is by any action of any authority that may impinge on the freedom of the press, he can also file a complaint with the Council. The aggrieved newspaper or journalist may inform the Council about the possible reason for the action of the authorities against him i.e. if it is as a reprisal measure taken by the authorities due to critical writings or as a result of krisan the policy that may affect the freedom of the press (supporting documents, with English translation if they are in a South Asian language, should be filed). A declaration regarding the non-pendency of the matter in any court of law is also necessary.
On receipt of a complaint made to it or otherwise, if the Council is prima facie satisfied that the matter discloses sufficient ground for inquiry, it issues a show cause notice to the respondents and then considers the matter through its Inquiry Committee on the basis of written and oral evidence tendered before it. If, on inquiry, the Council has reason to believe that the respondent newspaper has violated journalistic norms, the Council keeping in view the gravity of the misconduct committed by the newspaper, warns, admonishes or censures the newspaper or disapproves of the conduct of the editor or the journalist as the case may be. It may also direct the respondent newspaper to publish the contradiction of the complainant or a gist of the Council’s decision in its forthcoming issue.
Similarly, when the Council upholds the complaint of the aggrieved newspaper/journalist the Council directs the concerned government to take appropriate steps to redress the grievance of the complainant. The Council may, if it considers necessary, make such observations, as it may think fit, in any of its decisions or reports, respecting the conduct of any authority, including Government.

Honorary Doctorate from [[Florida Atlantic University]] | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Ralph de la Vega''' is the former Vice Chairman of [[AT&T]] Inc. and CEO of AT&T Business Solutions and AT&T International. He has previously served as President & CEO of AT&T Mobile & Business Solutions; President and CEO of AT&T Mobility; COO of [[Cingular Wireless]]; President of BellSouth [[Latin America]] Operations; and the President of Broadband and Internet Services for [[BellSouth]].Perdomo, Y. (November 2004) "Ralph De La Vega" ''Hispanic'' 17(11): pp. 28-9.Belson, K., et al., (Sept. 2004) "For Cingular, Becoming No. 1 Also Poses Risks" ''New York Times'' (Late New York Edition) (September 27, 2004) pp. C1, C4. He is also the author of the 2009 book ''Obstacles Welcome: How to Turn Adversity to Advantage in Business and Life''. Ralph de la Vega retired December 31, 2016, after a 42-year career with AT&T. ==Early life and education== Ralph de la Vega was born in Cuba, and emigrated to the United States in 1962, at the age of ten. In an effort to flee the [[Fidel Castro|Castro dictatorship]] in that country, his family attempted to board a plane to [[Miami]]; however the border official stated that only Ralph's papers were in order. He was sent to the US alone, where he stayed with the friend of an aunt. It took four years for his parents to join him.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TCwpJ6svetsC&pg=PT27|title=86400|publisher=}} Once his parents arrived, de la Vega took an after-school job sweeping the floors of a garment factory to help support the family. He was then promoted, and started making money selling the clothing made by the company.{{cite web|url=http://views.washingtonpost.com/leadership/books/2011/03/obstacles-welcome.html|title=Leadership Books: Reading 'Obstacles Welcome' - getAbstract|publisher=}} De la Vega eventually enrolled in a pre-engineering curriculum at [[Miami Dade College]], and worked part-time as a draftsman at an engineering firm. He then received his bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from [[Florida Atlantic University]]. He later received an MBA from [[Northern Illinois University]].{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yxyV4dr1KfMC&pg=PA42|title=Hispanic Engineer & IT|publisher=}}{{cite web | title = Ralph de la Vega | publisher = Wireless Services from AT&T, Formerly Cingular | url = http://www.wireless.att.com/about/meet-us/ralph-de-la-vega.jsp | accessdate = 2008-02-13}} He also completed the Executive Program at the [[University of Virginia]] and received an honorary doctorate from Florida Atlantic.{{cite web|url=http://dga.kennesaw.edu/iaa.php|title=KSU - Division of Global Affairs - International Achievement Awards|publisher=}} ==BellSouth== De la Vega started his career in 1974 with [[BellSouth]] (then Southern Bell) as a management assistant.[https://people.forbes.com/profile/ralph-de-la-vega/8140], Ralph de la Vega Profile - Forbes.com Over the years he held positions in Network Planning, Consumer Services, Engineering, and DSL and Operations. In 1985 he became a director at the Bell's Communications Research Technical Education Center (Bellcore TEC). He was later made responsible for all BellSouth Telecommunications Network Operations in Florida, Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana. Afterwards he became the president of BellSouth Broadband Internet Services.{{cite web|url=http://www.ccdaily.com/Pages/Campus-Issues/Taking-the-telecom-industry-by-storm.aspx|title=Taking the telecom industry by storm|publisher=}} De la Vega eventually became the president of BellSouth Latin America, a role he held from 2002 to 2003.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=9172107&privcapId=100231|title=List of Public Companies Worldwide, Letter - Businessweek - Businessweek|work=Businessweek.com}} In this job he was in charge of the wireless subsidiaries in eleven countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Guatemala, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, Uruguay, and Venezuela. The CEOs of each company reported to de la Vega, who restructured the decision-making infrastructure of the group in order to create cooperative strategies and policies between the different firms. At the end of his first year as president, BellSouth Latin America turned a profit for the first time.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/08/20/ralph-de-la-vega-constructive-criticism/|title=How to Give Constructive Criticism - Fortune|author=Ralph de la Vega|date=20 August 2015|work=Fortune}} ==AT&T== De la Vega served as the chief operating officer of Cingular Wireless,{{cite web|url=http://politic365.com/2013/03/20/ralph-de-la-vega-author-executive-says-obstacles-welcome/|title=Ralph De La Vega, Author & Executive says, "Obstacles Welcome"|publisher=}} starting in 2004. In 2007 Cingular was acquired by SBC (itself later re-named AT&T),{{cite web|url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/14154/20140827/at-t-mobility-gets-new-ceo-de-la-vega-becomes-mobile-business-solutions-group-head.htm|title=AT&T Mobility gets new CEO, de la Vega becomes Mobile & Business Solutions group head|work=Tech Times}} and he was named CEO of AT&T Mobility.{{cite web|url=http://www.techradar.com/us/news/phone-and-communications/mobile-phones/at-t-s-de-la-vega-to-lead-newly-merged-wireless-and-business-units-1262943|title=AT&T's de la Vega to lead newly merged wireless and business units|author=Juan Martinez|work=TechRadar}} De la Vega was one of the leaders of the merger. At AT&T de la Vega formed relationships between the company's mobile unit and automobile manufacturers, including General Motors, in order to grow the company's market for car connectivity. He also pushed for promotions intended to draw subscribers away from AT&T's competitors. He also brought the iPhone to the company.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiercewireless.com/special-reports/3-ralph-de-la-vega-ceo-t-mobility-and-consumer-market|title=3. Ralph de la Vega, CEO, AT&T Mobility and Consumer Market|work=FierceWireless}} De la Vega was the CEO of AT&T Mobility until 2014, when he was promoted to President and CEO of AT&T's combined Mobile & Business Solutions group. One of the main goals of de la Vega in this position is to develop AT&T's role in the Internet of Things and to deliver integrated services to business customers.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/09/15/att-internet-of-things/|title=AT&T's plan for the Internet of things goes way beyond the network - Fortune|author=Stacey Higginbotham|date=15 September 2015|work=Fortune}} In 2016 he became the Vice Chairman of AT&T Inc. and CEO of AT&T Business Solutions and AT&T International.http://www.cnet.com/news/at-t-reshuffles-leadership-to-tie-video-mobile-services-together/http://www.att.com/gen/investor-relations?pid=9812 Ralph De la Vega retired from this position on 31 December 2016. ==''Obstacles Welcome''== In 2009 de la Vega coauthored the book ''Obstacles Welcome: How to Turn Adversity to Advantage in Business and Life'', with Paul Brown. De la Vega decided to write the work due to the response he was receiving after the speeches he delivered at speaking engagements. The goal of the book was to provide career and life advice to youth and young professionals.http://www.leadersmag.com/issues/2010.2_Apr/PDFs/delaVega.pdf The book contains "four pillars of success" and "six pivotal points" in which he uses his personal story to structure his advice. De la Vega has also written for periodicals including Cnet.http://www.cnet.com/20-years-of-tech/8/ ==Recognition== De la Vega was selected [[Senior management|Executive]] of the Year by the Association of Latino Professionals in Finance and Accounting and has been listed as one of America's "50 Most Important [[Hispanics]] in Technology and Business." He is a past member of the board of Junior Achievement of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], where he serves as the chairman of the JA Hispanic Initiative, a program to encourage Hispanic students to remain in school and prepare for success in the U.S. business world. In addition, he has served on the board of directors for the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and the Georgia Aquarium.{{cite web|url=http://www.rcreader.com/news-releases/ralph-de-la-vega-presidentceo-of-atat-mobility-to-speak-at-hispanic-chambers-gala-event/|title=Ralph de la Vega, President/CEO of AT&T Mobility, to Speak at Hispanic Chamber's Gala Event|author=Richard Martin|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20160220094009/http://www.rcreader.com/news-releases/ralph-de-la-vega-presidentceo-of-atat-mobility-to-speak-at-hispanic-chambers-gala-event/|archivedate=2016-02-20|df=}} He is a member of the [[National Executive Board of the Boy Scouts of America]], the organization's governing body[http://www.scouting.org/filestore/media/324-168.pdf Boy Scouts of America Annual Report 2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114024453/http://www.scouting.org/filestore/media/324-168.pdf |date=2012-11-14 }} and is a board member for the Georgia chapter of the Boy Scouts of America. De la Vega was featured in HBO's ''The Latino List pt.2'' where he discussed his background along with other impactful Latinos. In 2011 he was awarded the [[Emory University]]'s Global Innovation Award. He has also been a Trustee of [[Morehouse College]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hbo.com/documentaries/the-latino-list-volume-two/slideshow/portraits.html|title=HBO: The Latino List: Volume Two: Images|work=HBO}}{{cite web|url=http://www.emorybusiness.com/2011/09/20/att-executive-receives-innovation-award/|title=AT&T Executive Receives Innovation Award|work=EmoryBusiness.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.morehouse.edu/trustees/trustees.html|title=Morehouse|author=Morehouse College|publisher=}} ==See also== *[[List of chief executive officers]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ralphdelavega.com Official Website] * [http://www.att.com/gen/investor-relations?pid=9812 de la Vega biography at ATT.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Vega, Ralph}} [[Category:Florida Atlantic University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:National Executive Board of the Boy Scouts of America members]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Cuban businesspeople]] [[Category:Cuban emigrants to the United States]]

{{For|other people of this name|Robert Miller (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Robert Warren Miller | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1933|5|23}} | birth_place = [[Quincy, Massachusetts]], U.S. | citizenship = British | children = [[Pia Getty]]
[[Marie-Chantal, Crown Princess of Greece]]
[[Alexandra von Fürstenberg]] | parents = Ellis Warren Appleton Miller
Sophia June Squarebriggs | networth = US$2.3 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] (March 2016)[https://www.forbes.com/profile/robert-miller-1/ Forbes: The World's Billionaires – Robert Miller] March 2013 | spouse = Chantal Pesantes }} '''Robert Warren Miller''' (born May 23, 1933) is an American-born British billionaire, entrepreneur, [[co-founder]] of [[DFS Group|DFS (Duty Free Shops)]], and sailing [[champion]]. He is the father of [[Marie-Chantal|Crown Princess Marie-Chantal of Greece]], [[Princess Alexandra von Furstenberg|Alexandra Miller]], and [[Pia Getty]], dubbed by tabloids and high society as The Miller Sisters. ==Early life and education== Miller was born in [[Quincy, Massachusetts|Quincy]], [[Norfolk County, Massachusetts|Norfolk County]], Massachusetts, in 1933, the son of Ellis Warren Appleton Miller (1898 – c. 1986), a [[bookkeeper]], [[salesperson]], and descendant of several [[Mayflower]] passengers; and Sophia "Sophie" June Squarebriggs (1899–1998), a Canadian-born former [[governess]]. Miller's ancestry is rooted in the British North American colonial elite, and descends over time, he claims, from [[Henry I of England]], [[Louis IV of France|Louis IV the Carolingian]], and [[William the Lion|William, King of the Scots]].Julie Helen Otto & William Addams Reitwiesner, Some ancestry of the Miller sisters [http://www.wargs.com/royal/miller.html 1995]. Miller attended [[Cornell University School of Hotel Administration]] and graduated in 1955, with a Bachelor of Science in Hotel Administration. He was a member of the [[Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity]] and the [[Irving Literary Society (Cornell University)|Irving Literary Society]]. ==Career== ===Duty Free Shoppers (DFS)=== [[File:DFS-Okinawa2.JPG|thumb|400px|DFS's Okinawa venue.]] The concept of "[[duty-free shop]]ping" – offering [[high-end]] [[Concession (contract)|concessions]] to [[tourism|travelers]], free of [[import taxes]] – was in its infancy when, with [[Chuck Feeney]], Miller founded DFS on November 7, 1960. DFS began operations in Hong Kong, where it still maintains its corporate headquarters, later expanding to Europe and other continents. DFS' first major breakthrough came in the early 1960s, when it secured the exclusive concession for duty-free sales in Hawaii and Hong Kong, allowing it to market its products to Japanese travelers.Dermot Davitt, The Moodie Report, November Personality of the Month: Robert Miller (June 6, 2010). DFS eventually expanded to off-airport duty-free stores and large downtown Galleria [[Retailing|stores]], and became the world's largest travel retailer.{{cite web|url=http://www.dfsgalleria.com/Galleria/English/Global/Global_About_DFS.html|title=Duty Free Shopping Stores – DFS T Galleria & Airport Shops|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} In 1996, Feeney's interests were acquired by [[Louis Vuitton]] [[Moët]] [[Hennessy]] ([[LVMH]]), the French [[luxury good]]s group, for $1.63 billion.{{cite web|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3755/is_199703/ai_n8761288|title=FindArticles.com – CBSi|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} Miller kept his shares and remains a significant minority shareholder (38%) in DFS alongside LVMH,{{cite book | title=Luxury Brand Management | publisher=John Wiley & Sons | author=Chevalier, Michel | year=2012 | location=Singapore | isbn=978-1-118-17176-9}} which bought out Feeney's share. More recently, Miller targeted the emergence of mainland China's economic elite. To present its new merchandise, DFS has moved beyond the airport liquor store venue and into store environments, seeking to market the broadest portfolio of brand names in the travelling marketplace. In 2010, the DFS Group had an estimated sales of about €2.2 billion. As of 2012, it has 150 stores in 15 Pacific states. Its downtown activities operate under the Galleriera name. Miller was named the November 2010 Personality of the Month by The Moodie Report in recognition of his advancement of the luxury goods industry's cause. That year, Duty Free Shops (DFS) celebrated its 50th anniversary at the DFS Galleria Sun Plaza store in Hong Kong, with a gala attended by 2000 guests, and featuring a performance by [[Wyclef Jean]].William Stolerman, DFS Celebrates 50th With Star Studded Gala in HK (Nov 21, [2010]).Dermot Davitt, The Moodie Report, Picture Gallery: DFS celebrates 50th anniversary in Hong Kong (July 11, [2010]). ===Search Investment Group Ltd=== In 1973, Miller founded Search Investment Group Ltd, an international investment company of which he is CEO and chairperson. The Search investment Group Ltd is a large shareholder in Ortelius Capital Partners, which is an investment firm founded by Miller's son-in-law HRH Prince Pavlos of Greece and Mr. Peter DeSorcy.{{cite web|url=http://www.searchgroup.com/|title=Search Investment Group|accessdate=July 29, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.orteliuscapital.com|title=ortelius-aim|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} He is also principal of SAIL advisors (Search Alternative Investments Ltd), global investors in hedge funds. Along with other assets, Miller is currently ranked the 68th wealthiest person in the UK,{{cite web|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/section/0,,20590,00.html|title=The Times & The Sunday Times|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} down from 22nd in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/richlist/person/0,,33629,00.html|title=The Times & The Sunday Times|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} ==Sailing records== In October 2003, Miller's [[monohull]] [[yacht]], the Mari-Cha IV, set a new [[world record]], becoming the first [[monohull]] ever to cross the Atlantic Ocean in under seven days. [https://web.archive.org/web/20040929151518/http://www.mike-sanderson.com/default.asp?m=da&id=9977] During the same crossing, the yacht also broke the 24-hour distance record, by sailing {{convert|525.5|nmi|km|1}}. Both he and his son-in-law [[Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece]], son of King [[Constantine II of Greece]] were crew members. On April 30, 2005, the Mari-Cha IV won the Rolex Transatlantic Challenge and broke the century-old record for a west-to-east transatlantic crossing established by [[Charlie Barr]]. It completed the 2,925-nautical mile passage across the North Atlantic between New York and England in a time of 9 days, 15 hours, 55 minutes and 23 seconds—a full 2 days, 12 hours, 6 minutes and 56 seconds faster than the record set 100 years earlier.Mike Hanlon, Century-old Transatlantic Challenge Record Broken (April 30, 2005). During the record-breaking crossing, Miller pushed the Mari-Cha III beyond its limits in poor weather, and the mainsail headboard and the headboard cars on both mainsail and mizzen broke. ==Personal life== Miller is married to Ecuadorian-born María Clara "Chantal" Pesantes Becerra,http://www.wargs.com/royal/miller.html they have three daughters: [[Pia Getty|Pia]] (b. 1966), [[Marie-Chantal, Crown Princess of Greece|Marie-Chantal]] (b. 1968), and [[Princess Alexandra von Fürstenberg|Alexandra]] (b. 1972) He also owns the {{convert|36000|acre|km2|0|sing=on}} Gunnerside Estate in [[Yorkshire]], one of the largest sporting country estates in [[Great Britain|Britain]]. ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= Robert Warren Miller |2= Ellis Warren Appleton Miller |3= Sophie June Squarebriggs |4= Ellis John Springer Miller |5= Blanche Louise Appleton |6= Altimus Squarebriggs |7= Priscilla Mountain |8= Charles Herman Miller |9= Elizabeth Ann Springer |10= George Henry Appleton |11= Helen Mary Edson |12= Hugh Squarebriggs |13= Jane Clark |14= James S. Mountain |15= Mary Margaret Wallace |16= John Miller |17= Huldah Grey? |18= John Springer |19= Eliza Ford |20= Joseph Warren Appleton |21= Rebecca Samuels |22= John Morton Edson, 5th great grandson of [[John Howland]]{{cite journal|last1=Reitwiesner|first1=William Adams|title=Etude 51|journal=Cercle d'Etudes des Dynasties Royales Europeennes|year=1995|volume=Bulletin No. 63 & 64}} |23= Mary H. Stevens |24= |25= |26= James Clark |27= Eliza Bell |28= James Mountain |29= Ann Donald |30= William Victor Wallace |31= Mary Donald }} ==Associations== Miller is a trustee of the Asia Society, the Independent non-executive director and Member of the Remuneration Committee of Hong Kong and Shanghai Hotels Ltd., and presidential councilor and trustee emeritus of Cornell University. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Miller, Robert W.}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American billionaires]] [[Category:American people of Canadian descent]] [[Category:Cornell University School of Hotel Administration alumni]] [[Category:People from Quincy, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Hong Kong businesspeople]] [[Category:Hong Kong people of American descent]] [[Category:Miller family]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
{{Use Jamaican English|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} '''Rose Agatha Leon''' (20 October 1913 – 16 August 1999) was a Jamaican businesswoman and politician. In August 1999, she was murdered in her home.<ref> {{cite news | first = Glenroy | last = Sinclair | title = Madame Leon slain | date = 17 Aug 1999 | url = http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/19990817/f1.html | work = Jamaica Gleaner | accessdate = 2013-08-25 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071111181717/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/19990817/f1.html | archivedate = 11 November 2007 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
==Biography== ===Politics=== In 1948, she became the first woman to chair a national political party, the [[Jamaica Labour Party]], holding that position for 12 years.<ref name="guardian"> {{cite news | first = Yvette | last = Rowe | title = Rose Leon, Outspoken Jamican politician who always put people first | date = 23 August 1999 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/news/1999/aug/23/guardianobituaries1 | work = The guardian | accessdate = 2013-08-25}}</ref>In 1949, she was elected into the house of representatives, and in 1953 was appointed minister of health and social welfare.<ref name="Women Leadership"> {{cite web | url = http://www.guide2womenleaders.com/Jamaica.htm | title = Worldwide Guide to Women in Leadership | accessdate = 2013-08-25}}</ref> In 1960 she left the JLP due to its lack of support for the [[Federation of the West Indies]]. Soon after, she switched sides and joined the [[People's National Party]], returning to prominence in the late 1960s as a local councillor, and in 1971 as deputy mayor of Kingston. <ref name="guardian"/>From 1972-76 she was Minister of Local Government in the [[Michael Manley|Manley]] government.<ref name="Women Leadership"/>
===Cosmetics business=== Having returned to Jamaica from studying chemistry in the US, she founded the Leon School of Beauty Culture with her husband. She pioneered a line of locally-made beauty products, providing an alternative to imports. Right up until her death, Leon taught at the school.<ref name="guardian"/>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leon, Rose}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:Jamaica Labour Party politicians]] [[Category:People's National Party (Jamaica) politicians]] [[Category:Jamaican businesspeople]] [[Category:Jamaican murder victims]] [[Category:Jamaican people of Hakka descent]] [[Category:Hakka politicians]] [[Category:Jamaican women in business]]
